 Economic Background and the Transport Sector I ARMENIA HIGHWAY PROJECT 1. ECONOMIC BACKGROUND AND THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. Economic Overview 1.1 Armenia is a small (29,800 sq km), mountainous, landlocked country with a population of 3.65 million. GDP per capita was estimated at $670 in 1994. With few natural resources and only 15 percent of the land able to be farmed, Armenians have survived through strong traditions of education and entrepreneurship. Armenia formally declared independence on September 23, 1991 and elected a reform minded government the following month. The government has proceeded to implement far reaching reforms including the removal of restrictions on external trade, the privatization of agricultural land and industrial enterprises, and serious attempts to control monetary and fiscal expansion. Since Armenia had a large but uneconomic industrial base within the Former Soviet Union (FSU) that depended in large part upon imports and exports to the other parts of the FSU, the dissolution of the FSU and the blockades by two of Armenia's neighbors related to the hostilities over Nagorno-Karabakh have had a devastating effect on the economy. GDP fell by 52 percent in 1992 to about one-third of its 1989 level, and a further 15 percent in 1993. The decline leveled off in 1994, with a real GDP growth of 5.4 percent according to government estimates. 1.2 The Government succeeded in reducing inflation from 46 percent per month in the first quarter of 1994 to 2 percent per month in the first quarter of 1995. This was accomplished through a stabilization program undertaken from the Spring of 1994, with IMF advice. Financial assistance from the IMF commenced in December 1994 with the approval of a Systemic Transformation Facility. These gains have been consolidated through the support of a Standby Arrangement with the IMF that was concluded in June 1995. In parallel the Government is undertaking a comprehensive structural reform program supported by a Rehabilitation Credit from IDA approved in February 1995. It will now be critically important to stimulate output in a stable economic environment that will attract long term sustainable investment as a means of raising living standards and relieving the severe shortages affecting the entire economy. A functioning road network is a vital precondition for achieving this strategy. B. Overview of the Transport Sector 1.3 The Government inherited one segment of the FSU road system, a minuscule part of the massive FSU railway network, and one segment of the FSU air transport system, along with the responsibility for transport infrastructure and rolling stock. The entire system, including the maintenance and repair facilities, were in need of substantial overhaul and repair. 1.4 The railway system consists of an electrified main track of 825 km, two short branch lines to Gumri and Lake Sevan, and two international links to the north and one to the south. There is also an out-of-gauge connection with Turkish railways at Ahurian. The rolling stock consists of 100 diesel and electric locomotives, many that are 20-25 years old, and 80 diesel locomotives for shunting. There

As spare parts are increasingly difficult to obtain, the locomotive fleet is now being cannibalized. 1.5 For air transport, Armenia acquired a collection of old and fuel-inefficient aircraft from the Aeroflot fleet, two major airports and six minor airports and strips. Armenia still shares arrangements with Aeroflot for fleet maintenance, reciprocal rights, and allocation of costs and revenues. The air freight business has already been turned over to a joint venture with a private company, while Armenia Airlines runs normal CIS passenger flights and international charters in collaboration with foreign agencies. The new terminal facilities at the Yerevan airport should be adequate, but the handling of both passengers and cargo is disorganized. 1.6 The Armenia national road network is adequate for the present level of traffic. Maintenance of the national network is carried out under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MTC), and an additional number of smaller roads are maintained by local and regional authorities. At the time of independence, the vehicle fleet included around 100,000 vehicles owned by Ministries and public enterprises. The average age of the fleet was over 7 years and the daily availability was only about 70 percent due to lack of maintenance. The MTC had 102 garages and workshops for carrying out repairs. Some of the workshops have been privatized and the balance are run on independent profit-making lines. It is the Government's policy to privatize as many of these activities as possible during the next several years.
 The Highway Sub-Sector 3 11. THE HIGHWAY SUB-SECTOR A. The Highway Network 2.1 Public Roads. The total road network in Armenia is just under 7,800 km (see Table 2.1), of which 77 percent are paved. The road network is divided into Interstate Highways (1,440 km), Regional Roads (2,621 km) and District Roads (3,727 km). The Interstate Highways include 60 km of four lane highways serving the highest density routes. The system includes 829 bridges, 13 of which are wooden. The mountainous terrain of Armenia determines where people can live, and in general also the need for location of the road networks. The existing road network with a density of 0.26 km per sq km is adequate for the traffic needs at this time. Traffic levels are very much lower than they were in the 1970s. This reflects the critical economic situation of the past few years when the size of the Armenian economy declined by more than 50 percent. Traffic counts on the Interstate road network were carried out in 1994 by TecnEcon (see para. 2.4), finding that nearly 83 percent of the network carries less than 3,000 vehicles per day. Heaviest traffic is concentrated on the dual highways radiating outward from Yerevan. Passenger car traffic accounts for around 75 percent of total vehicle kilometers, while heavy trucks of three or more axles make up only 8 percent of the total. Traffic will undoubtedly increase as the economy recovers from its seriously depressed present level, although no patterns have been established that can form the basis of an estimate of future growth. Other uncertainties relate to the future of the railway system, which is in need of massive investment to restore it to good condition and whose viability will affect road traffic patterns, and the closed borders with two of Armenia's neighbors, where their opening would also change the rate of use on several important routes. 2.3 Climate and terrain. Extensive areas of the highway network cross mountainous terrain and altitudes often exceed 1500 meters. Steep gradients, deep cuttings and high embankments are common in these areas, and landslides occur frequently. The severe winter climate, especially in the more mountainous areas of the country where heavy snowfalls are common, require substantial efforts
 4 The Highway Sub-Sector to maintain access. In many areas of the network, high intensity rainfall and poor road drainage cause traffic problems and road damage. The extreme climate has an influence on the behavior of road pavements, particularly as a result of the action of freezing and thawing in the spring. 2.4 Road conditions. The road conditions were surveyed in July 1994 by a consultant (TecnEcon) financed by EU-TACIS, and assisted by the Armenian Road Directorate (ARD). The result of the survey is summarized as follows: 8.3 percent Visible defects of less than 5% of surface. No structural failures; 54.7 percent Defects over less than 30% of surface. In general structure is still sound, but localized reconstruction of top pavement layer required; 27.3 percent Defects over at least one third of pavement area with some signs of early structural failure. Critical condition, but appropriate pavement seal will save structure; 5.0 percent Extensive evidence of significant structural failure. Extensive repairs to prevent complete failure; 4.7 percent Pavements have failed. Complete reconstruction required. The cost of the rehabilitation of this portion of the road network, as calculated by the consultant and modified somewhat when reviewed by IDA, is US$20.3 million (see Annex B). A visible inspection of a portion of the main road network in 1995 revealed that serious additional deterioration had occurred since the EU-TACIS-financed survey. It is apparent that the road pavements are now deteriorating at an accelerating rate, a trend that can be expected to continue until the road maintenance activities match the rate of deterioration. Based on an extrapolation of this study, the total cost of the deferred maintenance for the entire road network is in excess of US$100 million. 2.5 Budget constraints starting in 1990 and accelerating through 1994 required ARD to reduce its pavement maintenance operations drastically. In 1994, the total road maintenance budget was only equivalent to US$2.4 million, and ARD had only received 20 percent of this amount by the end of the calendar year. This amount, less than one percent of the 1990 road maintenance budget, was not enough even to carry out the routine maintenance operations for the national road network such as the filling of potholes. B. Road Safety 2.6 The road safety situation in Armenia is very poor by international standards. The statistics show that the number of accidents and fatalities have declined during the past several years but this is due to the sharply declining traffic volumes and poor accident reporting. While no reliable figures exist for the number of vehicles in the country, a comparison of fatalities per 10,000 inhabitants in 1990, when traffic was at a more normal level, with 17 other countries with vehicle densities in the same general order of magnitude (100 vehicles per 10,000 inhabitants) such as Bolivia, Egypt, and the Philippines shows that the Armenian level of fatalities per 10,000 inhabitants was higher than all but two of these countries in 1990 before traffic levels declined.

C. Highway Organization 2.10 ARD, which operates as a semi-independent public agency under the authority of the MTC, has the responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the national road network. ARD has used the Armgiprodor Institute in Yerevan, another public body now functioning like a private organization, for the design of new roads, reconstruction and rehabilitation schemes, and for identification of maintenance activities. The Institute is also responsible for carrying out highway surveys and checking materials and workmanship. Another public organization, the Armgiprotrans Institute, has been responsible for the design of bridges and tunnels as well as several major highways. ARD also uses its own highway inspectors for quality control and cost assessments. Road construction and maintenance have been carried out by 37 state-owned District Enterprises and seven specialized construction enterprises that operate under the direction of ARD, although the construction companies have recently been merged into some of the District Enterprises.

The total current employment level in ARD-related operations was estimated by ARD to be 4,280 people in 1994. This is a reduction from about 10,000 people employed three years ago. The District Enterprises employ about 3,800 people (89 percent of the total number of employees), the central ARD office has 68 employees, and the rest are employed by the Institutes. 2.14 ARD personnel appear to be competently trained in engineering skills. However, the engineering staff has been isolated from the advances in road techniques developed in the Western economies over the last few decades. Also, there is a general lack of awareness by ARD's staff of the techniques for using cost analysis as a basis for making choices regarding pavement management strategies, materials and equipment, as well as knowledge about contracting and procurement procedures. D. Privatization 2.15 Under the Government's general policy of privatization, the Armgiprodor Institute has been partially privatized. The employees rent the company's facilities from the Government, and income is limited to the contracts that the Institute can obtain on a paying basis from clients, most of whom are Government agencies such as ARD. Also, private engineering firms have begun to emerge, and a few are capable of providing services to ARD for road design and supervision. The Government has announced that it intends to continue to privatize substantial portions of the economy, and the 37 District Enterprises have been put on the Government's 1995 privatization list. Privatization will be carried out under the Privatization Act of 1992, under which the privatization process is being regulated. The first step in the process is to issue certificates of entitlement to shares of 20 percent of the value of the enterprise to the employees based on longevity and position within the firm. These certificates are to be converted into shares at no cost to the employees at the time the privatization takes place, which occurs when the Privatization Commission has placed a value on the stock and put the remaining 80 percent up for sale. In the interim while waiting for the privatization to take place, each enterprise will be placed under a Managing Council, with 40 percent of the members elected by the employee certificate holders and 60 percent appointed by the Ministry of Transport and Communications. The Council will elect a President and will appoint an Executive Director to manage the enterprise, which will begin to function like a private company even before its legal status is changed. After the stock sale takes place, the enterprise becomes a fully private stock company, owned and controlled by its stockholders. 2.16 During the interim period, the Government is not expected to subsidize the partially privatized entities. The ability of the privatized enterprises to survive will depend on how quickly and well they acquire new skills in business management, cost accounting and control, bidding and contracting, and quality control. For ARD, this will mean that its staff will have to acquire new skills in contract management, including contracting procedures and quantity and quality control, since all civil works functions irncluding routine and winter maintenance will be carried out on a contract basis. E. Highway Planning and Expenditures 2.17 Planning and Expenditure Procedures. Before independence, the highway authority organization obtained its budget from Moscow, which was agreed between the GOSPLAN in Moscow and the Armenian Government. Traditionally 20 year road development programs were prepared and

Since independence, budgets are requested through the MTC to the Ministry of Finance and passed on to the ARD. 2.18 A characteristic of the Armenian highway maintenance program is related to the weather conditions. The construction season during which bitumen products can be applied for surface dressings and overlays is generally limited to the May through October period because of the climate. Somewhat balancing the summer workload, the winter season requires snow clearing and sand/salt spreading to keep the roads safe and open to traffic. However, the unpredictability of the winter conditions makes the planning and budgeting during the winter season difficult. 2.19 Budget Levels. Road User Charges 2.21 During the Soviet era, funds were collected from enterprises, collective farms and trade organizations by a form of business turnover tax devoted to upkeep of the road network. These taxes are no longer collected due to the low level of business activity, and so there are virtually no road user charges in effect in Armenia at this time. Several months ago, however, as part of a package of measures worked out with the IMF, the Government put forward to the Parliament a proposal for a vehicle registration fee to be charged for all vehicles at a rate equivalent to about US$7 per vehicle, which has now been put into effect. Also, an import duty was proposed at a rate of 10 percent for all fuel imports from non-CIS countries (the Government stated that it could not impose an import duty on CIS goods because of a reciprocal agreement with the CIS countries). These proposals are still under consideration by the Parliament. It is not possible to estimate accurately what collections will be generated by these taxes since there are no reliable statistics on imports of fuel from non-CIS countries. However, it is unlikely that the total of both taxes and fees will exceed the equivalent of US$2 million per year in 1995 even if approved by the Parliament and if fully collected. 2.22 During project preparation, Government agreed on the need to increase road user charges. It is now putting into effect a revised schedule of road user charges to be used for the maintenance of national and local roads. Collections are expected to begin in 1995. The principal source of revenue will be a charge on the total revenue of all enterprises at the rate of 0.4 percent except for transportation companies, where the tax will be 2.0 percent. Estimated income from this source is estimated to be on the order of US$5 million in 1995, rising to higher levels in future years as the economy improves. 2.23 The Government is also carrying out a study of additional road user taxes and charges to augment or replace the enterprise tax, including the following: -Fuel taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel for vehicles
 The Highway Sub-Sector 11 -Transit tax -Axle load tax on large trucks -Tax on the procurement of buses and trucks. The level of the taxes has not yet been fixed, and the collection mechanisms present some problems that require careful study. One such problem is that fuel in Armenia is imported in small quantities on trucks and sold in 20 liter jerrycans at temporary sites alongside the road. This makes tax collection difficult, especially since the authorities would like to tax road users of diesel without taxing the use of diesel for other purposes such as for generators or farm machinery. The study will consider solutions to these problems and is expected to provide a basis for Government decision and action when it is completed. 2.24 In the longer run, the Government will need to make provision to collect a sufficient level of revenues from road users to finance an adequate level of road maintenance for the national road network. That level is difficult to calculate under present unstable economic conditions, but is on the order of US$25 million (the maintenance budget under the old system was around US$60 million, a level that was probably excessive). An amount of this size is beyond Armenia's present ability to raise, given the present state of the economy (total Government revenues in 1995 from all sources for all purposes is now estimated to be about US$180 million). However, the increase in revenues will have to be phased in gradually as the economy recovers in order to avoid aborting the recovery. Also, the institutional and technical improvements for highway maintenance included in the project are expected to yield savings in the cost of maintenance, but some operating experience with the new procedures will be needed in order to make an accurate estimate of the level of funding required for future maintenance operations. G. Design and Construction 2.25 Road classification and design standards. The Armenian roads are classified into five categories defined on the basis of traffic volume only. The design standards are based on those used by the former Soviet Union. The geometric standards of the existing roads are generally adequate except in difficult mountainous terrain where hairpin bends and other reduced standards are common. The road carriageway and shoulder design width are often too wide for the present traffic needs. The original pavement design was adequate, and in most cases the bearing capacity of correctly constructed roads will suffice subject to axle-loads being controlled and pavements maintained. However, with an expected increase of heavy load traffic on some international routes, pavement strengthening will be required, and drains, which are often substandard, will need upgrading. 2.26 Condition survey. Regular visual highway inspections were carried out on parts of the network in the spring and autumn of each year, but the survey and reporting system was poor. Roughness surveys have also been carried out over a part of the network every year, but the equipment used has not been calibrated to any standards. The equipment used for these surveys is described more fully below. 2.27 Axle load information. Although the pavements of the most recently constructed main roads are designed to the Soviet GOST design standards based on 10 tons standard design axle load, most roads are constructed for 6 ton axle load only. Presently the legal single axle load limit is 10 tons, but no information is collected on actual axle loads. ARD is aware, however, that loads of scrap metal and bulk goods considerably heavier than this limit are being hauled on the highways, causing serious wear

It contains detailed construction data, including road curvature and elevation, camber cuttings and embankments, and details of structures such as retaining walls and culverts. Some information on roughness and skid resistance is stored, but nothing is yet available on pavement strength, pavement layer thickness, cracking, rutting or any other defect types. No traffic data is recorded. Up- to-date accident data is available, but not sufficiently complete to satisfy the need for accident analysis and is not recorded in the road database. The database is being developed on the principle of providing maximum detail from the beginning so that only a small part of the network is covered. From a maintenance and pavement management point of view it would have been more useful to have started with less detailed data covering the whole main road network and then adding the detail as and when available. Most crucially, no network wide data referencing system has been established and inventory and condition data are intermixed and usually stored in terms of averages and general descriptions. 2.29 Highway inventory. A file ("passport") is kept for each route in which details about the route are stored. These are maintained manually on paper, and are not up-to-date. The file contains road section lengths, the location of highway structures along the route and sometimes when highway maintenance was carried out. Much information is duplicated, but there is no information on road signs, road markings, guardrails, speed limits, or details of pavement construction. Unfortunately the road file information is of limited value for maintenance planning. 2.30 Highway survey equipment. The Armgiprodor Institute has several items of Russian made highway survey equipment, including: a falling weight deflectometer (FWD); two towed bump integrators; a towed skid resistance wheel; and two Russian-made survey buses with on-board equipment for measuring horizontal and vertical alignment, rutting and distances. The FWD equipment and one of the survey buses have never been used because they were delivered incomplete and lack the software and user instructions required to run the equipment. The skid resistance wheel has inherent deficiencies in the way it is operated, and its results are unlikely to be reliable. One of the bump integrators is working, but it is not in good condition. 2.31 Laboratory testing facilities. The Armgiprodor Institute has laboratory testing facilities with a limited amount of equipment for testing cement, concrete, aggregate, soil and rudimentary bitumen samples. The equipment available for these purposes includes presses, bitumen penetrometers and viscosity measuring, cube making and other common devices. All the equipment is said to work. 2.32 Materials. Bitumen for road construction and maintenance came in the past entirely from Russia, and the quality varied. Because of import difficulties from Russia, recently some bitumen has been imported from Iran. Armenia has granite rock suitable for stone aggregate production in a few places only, but has a substantial supply of basalt of marginal quality. 2.33 The combination of woefully inadequate financial resources, physical difficulties to import because of the blockade by Turkey and Azerbaijan, and substantial price increases have caused considerable shortage of essential highway maintenance supplies. The 1993 bitumen consumption was only 15 percent of the 1991 quantity, there is a continuous shortage of fuel, ARD's spare parts stores are empty, and much equipment is being cannibalized to keep the most necessary units running. 2.34 Construction quality. Almost all of the road network was constructed during the FSU
 The Highway Sub-Sector 13 period to a generally adequate design standard, followed by a period of generous maintenance. However, poor quality control and poor workmanship have offset these advantages. In particular poor drainage provisions, poor compaction, poor control of vertical finish, incorrect grading of aggregate, use of unsuitable types of bitumen for surface dressing, and uneven bitumen distribution have resulted in a road network with many problematic areas where reconstruction/strengthening is now required. 2.35 Although little maintenance has been carried out since 1991 in Armenia, some stretches of the network have received surface dressing and pothole repairs. However, the quality of these treatments has generally been poor. Patched potholes are not cut out cleanly or properly filled and compacted. Consequently, they do not stop further deterioration, and treatment is often required at the same place within a year or two. Although greater care appears to be taken when surface dressing is carried out, substantial damage to the treated pavement occurs because the road is opened to traffic immediately after the treatment has been applied, with no speed restrictions in force. As a result, significant stripping occurs, and poor control of the quantities of bitumen applied to the road surface results in extensive areas of bleeding. H. Environmental Procedures and Issues 2.36 Until recently, environmental considerations were given only marginal consideration. The Armgiprodor Institute provided limited consultant services to determine pollutant counts from alternative materials relative to asphalt production, but has had no experience with the application of either mechanical or electrical filters for effluents. After serious environmental problems with their chemical industry, Lake Sevan and a debate about reopening of the nuclear power station, the public is now more environmentally aware than in the past. In 1991 the Ministry of Nature and Environment (MNEP) was established with responsibility for making policy and promulgating standards relevant to environmental protection. Regulatory and licensing systems were put in place that require the consideration of environmental issues in the design and implementation of development projects. The MNEP must sign off on all designs for road works, and MNEP-issued licenses are required for the operation of all quarries. Also, the MNEP is in the process of preparing a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP), which will be ready by June 30, 1997, as well as reviewing a variety of policies and regulatory standards. In addition, the State Engineering University now offers a Masters degree course in Environmental Engineering. In general, the measures already in place and under preparation appear to be adequate to safeguard the environment in connection with road work.

In March 1993 an Institution Building Loan (Ln. No. 3585-AM) was approved, directed to providing institutional support to government institutions that are critical to the restructuring of Armenia's economy. This was followed by an Earthquake Rehabilitation Credit (Cr. No. 2562-AM) for the reconstruction of houses and industry buildings in the area most severely affected by the 1988 earthquake. Also, a Power Maintenance Credit (Cr. No. 2666-AM) to strengthen the energy sector and an Irrigation Rehabilitation Credit (Cr. No. 2667- AM) were approved on December 8, 1994 and a Rehabilitation Credit (Cr. No. 2683-AM), designed to support the Govermnent's reform program through the provision of foreign exchange to finance critically needed imports, was approved on February 28, 1995. B. Country Strategy and Rationale for IDA Involvement 3.2 The key objectives of the Bank's country assistance strategy for Armenia as outlined in the Rehabilitation Credit are to deepen structural reforms to complete the transition to a market economy and to alleviate the large pockets of poverty that have emerged over the last few years. In terms of structural reforms, emphasis is being placed on promoting private sector development and establishing a targeted system of social protection. Sector specific interventions to complement the economy-wide efforts will focus on the delivery of social services, on energy efriciency and on the rehabilitation of critical infrastructure. While overall transport infrastructure is generally considered adequate to meet the short term requirements of the economy, there is an urgent need to prevent the further deterioration of the road network, particularly for those routes that connect Armenia to its sources of essential imports and to its export markets. In the longer run, there is a need to improve the efficiency and adequacy of road maintenance operations, and to build an effective maintenance organization that can develop a road network that is adequate to meet the needs of the expected expansion of road traffic as the economy expands. C. Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Projects in the Highway Subsector 3.3 The proposed project will be the first Bank/IDA highway project for Armenia. However, the Bank has had considerable experience in financing highway projects in other parts of the world, including Eastern Europe. Much of the Bank's lending for highway operations was for road construction up to about 1980. However, the road building boom of the 1960s and 1970s created an infrastructure that began to deteriorate rapidly in the late 1970s. Road networks had expanded much faster than the corresponding maintenance budgets and institutional capacities. Traffic was also increasing at a higher than projected rate, and axle loads often exceeded the design capacity of pavements. The serious magnitude of the problem was demonstrated in a policy study undertaken by the World Bank in 1987.1 The study, which analyzed the extent of deterioration of inter-urban main road networks in 85 countries receiving highway subsector assistance from the Bank (including IDA), came to some startling 'World Bank Policy Study. Road Deterioration in Developing Countries: Causes and Remedies. 1988.
 The Bank's Experience and Strategy 15 conclusions. A quarter of the paved roads outside urban areas required reconstruction in the mid-1980s, as did a third of unpaved roads. In addition, another 40 percent of the paved roads of these countries required strengthening. The estimated cost of restoring these roads was US$90 billion. If the countries did not improve their management of roads, the eventual cost could easily increase by two or three times, and the cost to road users would rise even more. 3.4 Concerned at the ever-growing backlog of road maintenance in borrowing countries, the Bank has adopted many of the recommendations of the above policy study in its sector work and investment projects. These include: (a) improvement in road planning and programming, including more reliable information and management methods and the application of economic criteria, (b) strengthening and reform of institutional performance, particularly by contracting out more maintenance activities to the private sector, (c) reallocation of resources to balance construction and maintenance with increased allocation of expenditures to reduce the maintenance backlog, and (d) improving the financing of roads, particularly by the adoption of rational road user charge systems. Lending for roads is generally conditional on countries having an appropriate balance of expenditure among new construction, restoration and maintenance, depending on the level of road deterioration, and on having a system of road user charges that generates most of the resources needed to keep the roads in reasonable condition. 3.5 Also, the experience with the Earthquake Rehabilitation Project provided valuable lessons about how to create competitive conditions in the construction industry. While the Highway Project will involve different companies and Government institutions, these lessons have been drawn upon in the design of this project, as has the Bank's experience with road maintenance generally. D. Highway Sector Strategy for Armenia 3.6 The recommendations of the Bank's Road Deterioration Policy Paper are reflected in the Armenian government's strategy for the highway subsector, along with other factors that are specific to the Armenian situation. The strategy includes: (a) restructuring the highway maintenance organization by turning over the maximum amount of its operations to private sector contractors operating on a competitive basis, (b) building a small but strong road management organization that utilizes the most efficient technology and effective quality control over the private contractors that it employs, (c) developing a competitive contracting industry for both construction and periodic and routine maintenance; (d) improving road planning, including the development of various road management systems; (e) shifting the utilization of budget resources to an emphasis on maintenance rather than new construction, and (f) instituting road user charges as a basis of providing the resources needed for an adequate level of maintenance. 3.7 In the past, the level of road maintenance was adequate, but budget constraints during the past three years have reduced maintenance activities below the levels needed to preserve a functional road system. Also, some of the materials and equipment used in highway maintenance were of inferior quality, construction and maintenance equipment is now old and technically inferior, and operational systems have not kept up with improved methods now in use in most developed and some developing countries. The transition from an operation run entirely as a state enterprise to private contracting has begun but is still in its infancy. 3.8 The challenge for Armenia is to increase its highway maintenance operations on an urgent
 16 The Bank's Experience and Strategy basis before pavement deterioration proceeds to the point where costly rehabilitation is required, and to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of its highway maintenance operations for the future. This will require a higher level of spending on periodic and routine maintenance in the short run, combined with the use of strict quality control, better equipment, and operational procedures including cost benefit analysis as a basis for decision-making. It also includes the strengthening of ARD so that it becomes an effective agency for managing the road maintenance program for the country, developing the skills necessary for operating the road maintenance program on a contract basis instead of by force account operations, privatization of the country's other road construction and maintenance organizations and developing an effective private sector construction industry that can carry out road maintenance and construction on a competitive basis. 3.9 The Bank's strategy for the highway subsector is to assist the Government in meeting this challenge through a lending operation that would support expanded maintenance operations with priority given to the main connecting routes that link Armenia to its sources of supply and its export markets, improvements in operational procedures and techniques used in road maintenance activities, and assisting in the institutional changes outlined in the previous paragraph, while encouraging the Government to increase the resources available to meet the future need for road maintenance through instituting appropriate road user charges. The project would also include assistance by several bilateral donors that are providing technical assistance and training in support of these objectives. The IDA credit would help to coordinate these various donor activities in the subsector. In the longer run, the Bank's strategy would include assistance to expand the road network's capacity as the need for this expansion becomes more apparent and if requested to do so by the Government. 3.10 The proposed project would, however, only meet a portion of the deferred maintenance requirements of the national road network, which exceed US$100 million based on the best available information at this time (see para. 2.4). The periodic maintenance requirements of the 1,411 km of paved Interstate highways were estimated to cost US$20.3 million based on the survey carried out by TecnEcon in 1994 (see Annex B), while the project provides for only US$18.6 million for this purpose. Furthermore, the pavements are undergoing continual deterioration, and the actual cost of this work will no doubt be greater because more costly forms of treatment will be required on some sections of road than was the case in 1994 when the study was made. Also, the project does not provide any financing for periodic maintenance for the remaining portions of the road network. While the project will make an important contribution to preserving the most important part of the network, substantially more funds will be needed to restore it fully, and a substantially higher annual budget allocation will be required to maintain the roads thereafter. Therefore, this project can be considered as an interim step in a longer process that will encourage the mobilization of domestic resources but which will also require further donor support in the future to address the large backlog of deferred maintenance. E. Government Attitude Toward Borrowing for the Highway Subsector 3.11 The Government is fully committed to the transition to a sustainable, growing market- based economy. It recognizes the need to maintain economic stability through the exercise of budget restraint, but also realizes the importance of an adequate level of maintenance in order to preserve the infrastructure that is critical for its future development. Specifically, it recognizes the key role of the highway network as part of that infrastructure. The Government sees foreign borrowing as a means of expanding its maintenance spending levels on a non-inflationary basis in the short run while it improves its ability to levy taxes through the introduction of user charges. At the same time, the Government is
 The Bank's Experience and Strategy 17 reluctant to borrow any more than necessary, and prefers to utilize grant funds for technical assistance requirements wherever possible. F. Budget Issues and Road User Charges 3.12 The Government's ability to carry out its strategy for the road sector will depend on its ability to generate the resources needed to do so. As described in para. 2.19, spending for road maintenance has been drastically reduced over the past three years because of the collapse of the Government's tax base. While foreign borrowing can mitigate the effects of that reduction for a limited period of time, over the longer run the Government must be able to generate the resources needed for maintenance from its own recurrent revenue collections. Also, road users should be required to pay the costs associated with maintaining the road network in order to put decisions made in the transport sector on a comparable basis with other transport modes. The newly proposed levies on fuel imports from non- CIS countries and vehicle registration fees are a move in the right direction but do not go far enough to meet the cost of road maintenance. The Government has already decided on some, at least interim, measures, as described in paras 2.22 and 2.23.

 Project Benefits and Sustainability 33 V. PROJECT BENEFITS, RISKS AND SUSTAINABILITY A. Project Benefits 5.1 Periodic Maintenance Component. The project would greatly increase ARD's capacity to carry out periodic highway maintenance of Armenia's public road network during a four year period (1996-1999), thus prolonging the life of the highway system and avoiding costly rehabilitation and reconstruction. The program would also reduce vehicle operating costs and maintenance as well as reduced road accident risks, making Armenia a more attractive investment choice for potential investors. An additional project benefit would be the experience that would be gained by the private construction industry in carrying out road maintenance work on a competitive basis. The Estimated Internal Rate of Return (EIRR) for the periodic maintenance component, which accounts for 57 percent of total project cost, is expected to be 38 percent compared to not carrying out the project, based on savings in vehicle operating costs and avoided costs of reconstruction. A sensitivity analysis was carried out with variable estimates of traffic growth. The results showed that the economic returns are relatively insensitive to quite large variations in assumed traffic growth, with most variations making no more than a two percent difference in the EIRR compared to the medium traffic growth estimate used in the basic calculation (see Annex B). The tunnel and bridge rehabilitation component (9 percent of total project cost) will only go forward if the calculated results show a positive net present value, based on a capital cost of 12 percent. No EIRR has been calculated for the routine maintenance component and supporting purchase of equipment (26 percent of total project cost), but typically routine maintenance has produced large savings in periodic maintenance costs. 5.2 Institutional Strengthening and Technical Improvement. This component provides for the radical reform of ARD through the redesign of its organizational structure and a revision in the way it carries out its responsibilities. The effect of these changes is expected to be improved cost- effectiveness in future highway maintenance through the use of cost-benefit analysis to determine pavement management strategies, competitive contracting, improved quality control, and improved technical methods through the introduction of new technologies and research. This component, which accounts for seven percent of total project costs, does not lend itself to conventional economic rate of return analysis, but typically reductions in maintenance costs through the adoption of similar techniques in other countries have been substantial. It would also result in the development of an effective road construction and engineering industry. 5.3 Road User Charges. The introduction of road user charges would result in an increased ability of the Government to provide financing for road maintenance in the future, thus putting the road network on a more sustainable basis. 5.4 Trade Facilitation. The maintenance of the main highway links to Armenia's external markets and suppliers would increase Armenia's prospects for economic growth and development. This is especially vital for a land-locked country with limited geographic access to other markets and with a railway system in serious need of rehabilitation.
 34 Project Benefits and Sustainability B. Project Risks 5.5 The major risks to the project are the ability of ARD to establish an effective road maintenance organization capable of carrying out the project activities, and the ability of the revised ARD to use contracting techniques effectively. Also the imposition of road user charges at a time when the economy is extremely depressed will be difficult and unpopular. And the importing of essential materials is difficult and uncertain, and adds to the difficulty of accurately estimating costs. Regarding the first point, this should be mitigated by the technical assistance being provided and the use of private contractors that are not Government employees for the civil works requirements. In regard to user charges, the Government has displayed keen interest in adopting a reasonable level of charges, and seems to recognize that this is essential for the maintenance of the road network. As to importing, while there are still some difficulties in this regard, the situation is improving as peace negotiations go forward. Regarding the use of contracts, provision has been made to provide guidance to ARD by IDA procurement specialists even before Board approval so that the bidding process gets off to a good start. Familiarization sessions will also be organized for local construction industry personnel. C. Project Sustainability 5.6 Project sustainability will depend to a large extent on the Government's ability to mobilize an adequate level of resources for road maintenance after the end of the project period and to adjust Government pay to reasonable levels after project disbursements are no longer available. This in turn will depend on the level and kind of road user charges that are enacted. The Government appears committed to the enactment of road user charges, and the kinds of charges that are under consideration are appropriate ones. The efficiency improvements expected from the improved systems, technical assistance and training components are likely to have a sustained impact on ARD's future operations if salary levels can be increased to levels adequate to retain its technical staff. Also, the development of the private road construction and engineering industries is likely to have a lasting impact.

 Anrex L Page 1 of 5 I. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The environmental review for the Armenia Highway Project (AHP) was conducted in March 1995 in conjunction with the appraisal mission for the AHP. The review addressed the requirements for IDA projects classed as "Category B" as opposed to the full Environmental Assessment (EA) required for "Category A" projects. The requirements for a full EA, however, were discussed as part of a workshop held under the sponsorship of IDA in conjunction with the conduct of the appraisal mission for the AHP.1 1.2 The conduct of the review included consultations with the Armenian Road Directorate (ARD), the Ministry of Nature and Environmental Protection (MNEP), the ARMGIPRODOR Design Institute, the Forestry Department of the Ministry of Agriculture, the Center for Environmental Management of the American University of Armenia (AUA), and the State Engineering University of Armenia (SEUA). Discussions with these agencies considered existing policies and procedures as well as inter-agency consultative practices. 1.3 The review found the road rehabilitation and maintenance proposed for the approximately 1440 kms of main highway under the AHP to be environmentally sound. Although there are several long-term considerations relative to the environmental impact of future road construction projects which will require further review, such issues lie outside the context of activities proposed for the AHP. II. DIRECT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS 2. 1 The environmental impact of most rehabilitation and maintenance projects in the road sector is seen as positive rather than negative. Assuming the retention of the existing alignments--as is the case in this project--such projects offer not only more efficient vehicle operation and a corresponding reduction in the emission of pollutants but also reduced noise and vibrations from traffic as well as the opportunity to introduce mitigation actions relative '/ The workcshop introduced road-related environmental issues within the broad context of future projects which might also include new road construction as well as maintenance.
 Annex L Page, 2 of 5 to existing threats.2 The major sources of directly negative impacts arising from maintenance projects, therefore, are considered to arise from (1) the production and application of bituminous products, (2) the quarrying of stone and gravels, and (3) such short-term impact as noise, dust, and the disruption of traffic resulting from the execution of work under the project. These three areas were each examined in the course of the review. 2.2 Asphalt Plant Production- According to the information provided by the ARD there were over 50 different asphalt plants which had been under the authority of the ARD and had been involved in the production of asphalt for the road sector (See Annex 1). When all were in production they had a combined capacity of about 2,240 tons per hour. The ARD reported that only about two-thirds of these plants were operational, and selected visual inspections indicated that the figure was probably even lower. The plants in the best condition--and seemingly the most efficient operations--were the ten Teltomat units produced in the former East Germany. Assuming that production were limited to these ten plants, the production of asphalt would be more than adequate in terms of the quantity of production and geographic distribution for the purposes of the AHP. 2.3 In view of the highly limited operation of any of these plants during the past two to four years, it was difficult to access either their efficiency or the potential threat from effluents and suspended particles, except on the basis of a review of historic data. This issue was discussed with both the ARD and the MNEP. Both organizations felt that since only the better plants would be put back in operation for the AHP, compliance with national regulatory guidelines could be maintained. Impact was expected to minimal, moreover, because only the plants located near Yerevan were adjacent to densely populated areas. If the plants near Yerevan failed to pass regulatory guidelines, they would not be used within this project. 2.4 QuaOrations- According to the ARD there were approximately 37 different quarries which had provided materials for use on road projects. About half of these produced gravels. The others either produced rock for subsequent crushing or maintained crushers on site to further process stone taken from the sites. The quantities estimated for the AHP did not indicate the need for opening any new sites. The quarry sites expected to be used for this project were distant from densely populated areas. 2.5 Instances were on record in the past when gravels were improperly taken from such non-quarry sites as river beds, resulting in at least one case in a change in the course of the river. In order to control such activities and to ensure minimum erosion and proper restoration after the conclusion of quarry operations, the MNEP has established a new licensing system for all quarry operations in Armenia. Under this new system all operations 2/ In those cases where rehabilitation under the project would require design, existing procedures would call for an assessment of the environmental impact of the proposed work. The review would be provided by ARMGIPRODOR or another design source and be subject to approval by the MNEP.

The AHP would use no sources for materials which were not licensed and reviewed under the new system. 2.6 Short-term Impact- Its is inevitable that there will be short-term impact from noise, dust, and traffic congestion during the execution of works. The minimization of such impact will be included in one of the modules on Construction Management which will be offered to the district enterprises as part of the training program under the project; certification of completion of these courses will be required by all enterprises interested in bidding on work funded by the project. Contractors will be required to prepare a mitigation plan for any site where the scale of impact is judged sufficiently significant; particular attention will be given to road segments adjacent to residential areas. INDIRECT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS 3.1 Indirect environmental impacts possibly arising from such a project as the AHP include such long-term developments as increased traffic growth and increased traffic speed. Although the rehabilitation and maintenance of the main network is a pre-requisite for such developments, a far higher correlation exists between such developments and national economic recovery. 3.2 The project does place considerable importance on the promotion of road traffic safety, and resources will be made available for the initiation of a meaningful road traffic safety program. Dialogue has already been initiated to ensure better communication and cooperation between the organizations responsible for road traffic safety, and technical assistance in support of road safety is to be provided under the project. The placement of signs along right of ways to indicate wildlife crossings would be included under this component. IV. INSTITUTIONAL AND REGULATORY CONSIDERATIONS 4.1 The Ministry of Nature and Environmental Protection, upgraded from the status of a State Commission in 1991, is the government organization responsible for making policy and promulgating standards relative to environmental protection. The responsibility and authority of the Ministry is broadly defined in Parliamentary decree No. 269, dated July 9, 1991. Included under its mandate is environmental public education, research, and the support for symbiotic solutions for infrastructure development and environmental protection. The MNEP is in the process of preparing the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) as well as reviewing a variety of policies and regulatory standards. 4.2 Regulatory and licensing systems currently exist which specifically require the consideration of environmental issues in the design and implementation of development

A review of regulatory procedures indicates the need for a more pro-active stance by the MNEP and design institutes relative to environmental protection. Increased attention should be given to consistent application of the existing policies and procedures and continued monitoring throughout the implementation of projects. This need was a subject discussed in the workshop referenced above. As an initial step in capacity building for managing future projects, this workshop also presented the basic documents and requirements of IDA relative to EAs. 4.3 Air pollution has been a major problem for urban areas in Armenia for at least two decades. Current levels have fallen as a result of the drastic down-turn in industrial production, but average levels in certain cities in the early 1990s exceeded the average daily Maximum Permissible Concentrations (MPC) by several times. Analysis included in the Environmental Sector Report for Armenia prepared in early 1995 included the production of construction materials--road materials being only one of several components-- among major contributors to the air pollution in two of the five most heavily impacted areas (Yerevan and Razdan).3 The MNEP is confident, however, that existing regulatory procedures are adequate to ensure compliance by the AHP with national standards; additional review would be required, however, for future projects involving major construction components. 4.4 Responsibility for environmental issues currently falls under the Technical Division of the ARD. The Chief Engineer heading this division participated in the workshop held during the Appraisal Mission and has been nominated for participation in a regional seminar on environmental issues to be held in mid 1995. Although the current levels of skills are adequate for the requirements of the AHP, training will be provided under the project as part of a long-term institutional strengthening effort to upgrade the capacity of the ARD relative to environmental issues. These findings needed to be reviewed by environmental and design specialists in Armenia. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Highway Project are to assist in preserving the Armenian road network, thereby avoiding costly rehabilitation or reconstruction at a later date, and to improve the efficiency of Armenia's road maintenance operations for the future. The specific objectives are to: 1) help preserve the Armenian national road network and reduce transport operating costs by expanding maintenance operations, including bridge and tunnel rehabilitation; 2) help develop an institutional framework adapted to the requirements of the road sector of a market economy; 3) expand the resource base for road maintenance by encouraging appropriate road user charges; and 4) assist in developing an effective private road construction and engineering industry; and 5) improve road safety. The project components are: 1) periodic highway maintenance; 2) bridges and tunnels; 3) materials for routine maintenance; 4) equipment and spare parts; 5) institutional strengthening and technical upgrading; and 6) project implementation.
